examples.sentence: Use particles to show grammatical role

sections.heading: What Makes Japanese Nouns Simple
sections.content:
Japanese nouns are remarkably straightforward:

No plural forms No gender No articles (a/the) Don't conjugate Use particles to show grammatical role

children.heading: No Plural Forms
children.content:
The same word works for singular and plural:

本 (hon) = book / books / the book / the books 犬 (inu) = dog / dogs / the dog / the dogs

Context or numbers clarify quantity:

本を読む - "read a book" / "read books" 三冊の本 - "three books" (number + counter clarifies) たくさんの本 - "many books" (quantity word clarifies)

children.heading: No Articles
children.content:
No "a" or "the" - context determines definiteness:

犬が好きです "I like dogs" (general) 犬を見ました "I saw a dog" or "I saw the dog" (context determines)

children.heading: No Gender
children.content:
Unlike French, Spanish, German - nouns have no grammatical gender:

テーブル (te-buru) - table (no gender) 椅子 (isu) - chair (no gender)

Gender only matters for people/animals when specifying:

男 (otoko) - man 女 (onna) - woman 雄 (osu) - male animal 雌 (mesu) - female animal

children.heading: Concrete Nouns
children.content:
Physical things you can touch:

本 (hon) - book 車 (kuruma) - car 家 (ie) - house 水 (mizu) - water

children.heading: Abstract Nouns
children.content:
Concepts and ideas:

愛 (ai) - love 時間 (jikan) - time 幸せ (shiawase) - happiness 問題 (mondai) - problem

children.heading: Proper Nouns
children.content:
Names of specific people/places:

日本 (nihon) - Japan 東京 (toukyou) - Tokyo 田中 (tanaka) - Tanaka (surname)

sections.heading: Noun Modification with の
sections.content: The particle の connects nouns to show possession or relationship:

children.heading: Possession
children.content: 私の本 watashi no hon "my book" 田中さんの車 Tanaka-san no kuruma "Tanaka's car"

children.heading: Description/Attribution
children.content: 日本の文化 nihon no bunka "Japanese culture" (literally: Japan's culture) 木の机 ki no tsukue "wooden desk" (literally: wood's desk)

children.heading: Location
children.content: 東京の会社 toukyou no kaisha "company in Tokyo" 図書館の本 toshokan no hon "library book" (book of/from library)

children.heading: Apposition
children.content: 学生の田中さん gakusei no Tanaka-san "Tanaka, who is a student" 友達の山田さん tomodachi no Yamada-san "Yamada, my friend"

sections.heading: Using Nouns with Particles
sections.content: Particles show the noun's role in the sentence:

children.heading: は - Topic Marker
children.content: 私は学生です "I am a student" (私 is the topic)

children.heading: が - Subject Marker
children.content: 犬がいます "There is a dog" (犬 is the subject)

children.heading: を - Direct Object
children.content: 本を読む "read a book" (本 is the direct object)

children.heading: に - Location/Direction/Time
children.content: 学校に行く "go to school" (学校 is destination) 机の上に本がある "book on the desk" (机の上 is location)

children.heading: で - Location of Action/Means
children.content:
図書館で勉強する "study at the library" (図書館 is location of action)

See: Particles Overview

sections.heading: Compound Nouns
sections.content: Japanese creates new nouns by combining existing ones:

children.heading: Kanji + Kanji
children.content: 電車 (densha) - train 電 (electricity) + 車 (vehicle) 電話 (denwa) - telephone 電 (electricity) + 話 (talk) 図書館 (toshokan) - library 図書 (books) + 館 (building)

children.heading: Native Japanese + Kanji
children.content: 飲み物 (nomimono) - drink 飲み (drink) + 物 (thing) 食べ物 (tabemono) - food 食べ (eat) + 物 (thing)

children.heading: Noun + Verb Stem
children.content: 買い物 (kaimono) - shopping 買い (buy) + 物 (thing)

sections.heading: Numbers and Counters
sections.content: Japanese uses counters when counting specific things:

children.heading: Basic Pattern
children.content: [Number] + [Counter] + の + [Noun] 三冊の本 (sansatsu no hon) - three books 二台の車 (nidai no kuruma) - two cars 五人の学生 (gonin no gakusei) - five students

children.heading: Common Counters
children.content:
〜冊 (satsu) - books, magazines 〜台 (dai) - machines, vehicles 〜人 (nin) - people 〜匹 (hiki) - small animals 〜本 (hon) - long objects 〜枚 (mai) - flat objects

See: Counter System

sections.heading: Nominalization
sections.content: Turning verbs or adjectives into nouns:

children.heading: Using こと
children.content:
Abstract nominalization:

泳ぐこと (oyogu koto) - swimming (activity/concept) 食べることが好き - "I like eating"

children.heading: Using の
children.content:
Similar to こと, more colloquial:

泳ぐの (oyogu no) - swimming 食べるのが好き - "I like eating"

children.heading: Using もの
children.content:
Concrete things:

食べ物 (tabemono) - food (thing you eat) 飲み物 (nomimono) - drink (thing you drink)

See: Nominalization

sections.heading: Nouns as Predicates
sections.content: Use です/だ to make nouns predicates:

children.heading: Present
children.content: 私は学生です watashi wa gakusei desu "I am a student"

children.heading: Past
children.content: 私は学生でした watashi wa gakusei deshita "I was a student"

children.heading: Negative
children.content: 私は学生じゃないです watashi wa gakusei janai desu "I am not a student"

children.heading: Proximity System (これ・それ・あれ)
children.content: これ (kore) - this (near speaker) それ (sore) - that (near listener) あれ (are) - that (far from both) どれ (dore) - which one?

children.heading: Usage
children.content:
これは本です "This is a book" それを見ました "I saw that" あれは何ですか？ "What is that over there?"

See: Demonstratives

sections.heading: Noun + です vs Adjective
sections.content: Don't confuse noun + です with adjectives:

children.heading: Noun + です
children.content: 学生です (gakusei desu) - "is a student"

children.heading: Na-adjective + です
children.content:
静かです (shizuka desu) - "is quiet"

Both look similar but na-adjectives need な before nouns:

学生の田中さん (noun + の) 静かな部屋 (na-adjective + な)

children.heading: Noun + する = Verb
children.content:
Many nouns + する become verbs:

勉強 (benkyou) - study → 勉強する - to study 掃除 (souji) - cleaning → 掃除する - to clean 電話 (denwa) - phone → 電話する - to phone 料理 (ryouri) - cooking → 料理する - to cook

children.heading: Noun + の + Noun
children.content:
Chain nouns with の:

日本語の勉強の本 nihongo no benkyou no hon "Japanese study book" (Book of study of Japanese language)

children.heading: Mistake 1: Adding Plural "s"
children.content:
Wrong: 本 s ❌ Right: 本 ✓

Japanese nouns don't pluralize.

children.heading: Mistake 2: Using Articles
children.content:
Wrong: a の本 ❌ / the の本 ❌ Right: 本 ✓

No articles in Japanese.

children.heading: Mistake 3: Wrong Particle with の
children.content:
Wrong: 私が本 ❌ (for possession) Right: 私の本 ✓

Use の for possession/attribution.

children.heading: Mistake 4: Confusing です/だ with Adjectives
children.content:
Wrong: 学生なです ❌ Right: 学生です ✓

Nouns use です directly, not なです.

children.heading: Mistake 5: Missing Counters
children.content:
Casual: 本三つ ❌ (without context) Better: 本三冊 ✓ or 三冊の本 ✓

Use appropriate counters with numbers.

children.heading: People
children.content: 人 (hito) - person 学生 (gakusei) - student 先生 (sensei) - teacher 友達 (tomodachi) - friend 家族 (kazoku) - family

children.heading: Places
children.content: 学校 (gakkou) - school 家 (ie) - house/home 会社 (kaisha) - company 店 (mise) - store 駅 (eki) - station

children.heading: Things
children.content: 本 (hon) - book 水 (mizu) - water 食べ物 (tabemono) - food 時間 (jikan) - time お金 (okane) - money

children.heading: Time
children.content: 今日 (kyou) - today 昨日 (kinou) - yesterday 明日 (ashita) - tomorrow 朝 (asa) - morning 夜 (yoru) - night

children.heading: Abstract
children.content: 言葉 (kotoba) - word/language 気持ち (kimochi) - feeling 考え (kangae) - thought/idea 問題 (mondai) - problem 理由 (riyuu) - reason

sections.heading: Noun Sentences Pattern
sections.content:
Basic noun sentence structure:

[Topic] は [Noun] です 私は学生です - "I am a student" これは本です - "This is a book" 東京は都市です - "Tokyo is a city"

Can add descriptions with の:

私は日本語の学生です "I am a Japanese language student" これは日本の本です "This is a Japanese book"

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
✓ No plural forms - same word for singular/plural ✓ No articles (a/the) ✓ No gender ✓ の connects nouns (possession/description) ✓ Particles show grammatical role ✓ Use counters when specifying quantity ✓ Noun + する often creates verbs ✓ Context determines specificity

Japanese nouns are simpler than English in many ways - no plurals, no articles, no gender to memorize. The challenge is learning when to use which particle and how to properly connect nouns with の.

Congratulations! You've completed the Basic Grammar Foundations section.

Next: Particles Overview

Related:

Parts of Speech の (no) Particle Nominalization Counter System
